Pohatu, Uniter of Stone

The first Toa of 2016 that I will review here is Pohatu. Since he was my first Toa last year, I feel that he should be one of the first ones reviewed here. For the Toa, I will critique them using some different methods, which are as follows:
Firstly, his mask is probably my favourite of the Toa this time around. I love that it&rsquo
column2: s the same mask as last year, but rounder. I like the crystal motif on his head and I very much like the design of the eyes on him. It makes him look a little alien, but I think that&rsquo
column3: s a strength of this mask design. The vents are still there, but they&rsquo
column4: ve been minimized from the big vents jutting out of the sides of his face last year. The mask is quite small, but I can&rsquo
column5: t help but love it. The Nuva symbols are there, as are a few cool looking runes. I especially love his transparent neon green melded golden mask&hellip
column6: which looks absolutely beautiful. It really helps make his eyes a very bluish green when placed on the figure. Probably my favourite stone mask ever created. 9/10

column1: His build is surprisingly fun. I originally thought I would be irritated by the way his arms are built, but to my relief discovered that it&rsquo
column2: s actually a neat little design. Of course, the build is one of the more simple ones of the Toa this year, but I think he definitely is much more complex than the version of him we saw last year. Other than his arms, there is the torso with the swivelling function, mind you mine squeaks very much, and the friction is very strong. I also enjoyed the building of his flail/spear. Otherwise, pretty general like last year. 8/10

column1: His weapon is very odd. I like the idea of a rock flail very much, in fact I would go as far as to hope that he gets a mace for a weapon come 2017, but I digress. I find it odd that they chose to combine the flail with a spear weapon, solely for the sake of the function. I do not feel that this was necessary, as you can easily leave a couple of the pieces used for his weapon, giving him just the flail which works just as well as it should. Otherwise, the weapon tends to not work well with his function, and that is not at all surprising. The chain flops somewhat forward when you swing him to one side, but it immediately comes back, likely due to the weight of the rock, to hit his knee. I like the creativity of the weapon and hope LEGO continues on this road for this character. Overall, I do not feel that this is one of the best weapons this time around unfortunately. 7.5/10

His arms, as I mentioned earlier, are very oddly constructed. Now, I originally thought I would dislike them very much, but having the set in hand, I find that they look quite good on him! I especially like the transparent neon green shells acting as bracers on his arms. I don&rsquo
column2: t mind the skinny look of the dark orange parts either. What is additionally even more impressive is how poseable his shoulders are, making his arms that much more moveable. The shoulder armour (definitely a plus over last year) is well placed and I like the accents of the bohrok eyes to the sides. Overall, decent looking arms. I do however prefer the generally more bulky look of the arms. 8/10

column1: His legs now have an even more pronounced boot look, which I very much like. I liked it on Pohatu last year, I greatly like it this year. I especially love the neon green crystal armour pieces, which look great on all the Toa this year as it gives Pohatu a more rugged look. Poseability of the legs is fantastic, but I am not sure how I feel about the colour change of the upper leg shells. Dark tan&hellip
column3: I have placed the two Pohatus together, and this is definitely subjective, but I find I like the dark orange much more than the dark tan. I don&rsquo
column4: t know why, I just don&rsquo
column5: t like it as much as I did the dark orange. Otherwise, well designed legs. 9/10

column2: s not much to really discuss here other than three things: colour, chest design, and proportions. I&rsquo
column3: ll begin with proportions, since I don&rsquo
column4: t mind it as much. What I&rsquo

I already mentioned this before, but the switch to dark tan is a bit strange. I actually do not like this colour as much as I liked the dark orange last year and really hope LEGO goes back to it. I appreciate the creativity of the colour, but personally, I don&rsquo
column8: t think it fits Pohatu well. Lastly, his chest design is also the result of experimentation and creativity, but, again, it doesn&rsquo
column9: t fit well for me. I think the desert camo look is interesting, and I definitely love the Stone nuva symbols printed onto the centre and sides. Out of all the Toa, I feel that Pohatu&rsquo
column10: s is my least favourite, but that does not mean I dislike it, it just means I like the other prints a little bit more. Overall, decent looking chest, I just wish there was more dark orange. 7.5/10

column1: Pohatu is loads of fun. You can split his weapon apart to form an actual flail and a spear/dagger thing, kind of like what he had last year, and you can even connect the spear to his back using the unity connections which I think is an accidental but awesome feature. The winging function really is fun, but it definitely does vary in terms of strength of friction (my Kopaka is very loose, for example). His arms are very poseable, as are his legs. I still do not like the fact that these Toa use more friction extenders, but I understand why they&rsquo
column2: re there. Combining Pohatu with Ketar brings additional play value, as you can use Ketar&rsquo
column3: s claws on Pohatu when they are both combined. As I mentioned in my review of Ketar, however, their unity mode is a bit flimsy and will take some getting used to. All in all though, I think Pohatu is pretty fun with and without Ketar. 8.5/10

column2: t think this Pohatu quite measures up to Master Pohatu from last year. I think this has to do with the colours, with the interesting weapon design from last year, and likely the fact that Master Pohatu was my first Toa purchased last year. I think that if you&rsquo

The other unities just seem to look better than this one does, although, if you play around with the unity mode here, you can definitely make these two look excellent together. If you&rsquo

column7: s a decent set and I like some of the ideas used in his design by LEGO, but I just feel they&rsquo
